I keep it a room that’s mostly white and seafoam green with a light grey flooring - not the room in the photo.Extremely easy to take apart- the side knobs come off- the handle comes off- easy to clean.Very well built circulator- worked right out of the box. Sturdy and all 3 speeds are powerful. Not real loud even on the highest setting.I get that the cords can’t be super long for a reason but another 10-12" would give more options for placement since you can not use extension cords with fans or circulators for safety reasons.Still a 5 star 🌟 machine. Definitely recommend!

Title: Liked these so much I just ordered another one for me and one for my daughter; decently priced
Review Content: I initially ordered 4 of these because it's been so hot and humid already this year that the demand on my whole house AC has caused it to struggle to keep things as cool as I like. These have been enough to keep the inside temperature nice and cool while not having to constantly adjust my AC temperature. I turn them on in the afternoon and they allow my AC unit to run more efficiently.  They came fully assembled and ready to go. They're loose inside the box so there's no packaging like styrofoam to mess with. The fans are very lightweight but steady on the floor, and they're easy to move around. I wasn't sure if I was going to like a floor fan, but they are actually pretty nice because you can tilt them up and down unlike the square box fans. That feature allows you not to have them blowing in you right in your face constantly. There are 3 settings - high, medium, and low. Unless you have more than one fan in the same room they are fairly quiet depending on the setting - high being the loudest, and low being the quietest. They haven't been too loud to have to try and talk over or hear the tv, except for the room that I have two in. It's still early summer, but come August when it's the hottest will be the real test. If things change at that time I will update my review. Right now, today, I am very pleased with their preformance and would highly recommend them.

This fan is all together the easiest most efficient  appliance in my house to plug in and go.  3 tilt positions, 3 speeds, no digital nonsense to fiddle with 6 buttons.  I buy a couple new fans every 3-4 summers.  I have had at least a dozen. Some in the $100s.  This fan is the best of the lot.  No one will dare borrow this one.  This fan is a treasure.

Title: Windmachine only
Review Content: Had one growing up because the top floor could never seem to get enough ac, I've been through tower fans, ceiling fans, stand up fans you name it and as an adult, find myself coming back to old reliable. Love the price. Love how long lasting. The one I used in my younger years was a hand me down from my brother's and lasted me three years after however long they wrecked havok on them for. Tried the fancy remote tower fans, the highest setting was to low and I mistakenly thought if it was pricier it would be more efficient, not the case. So now I have one in our bedroom and one in my workout room and they are amazing and I hope this style stays around and this company because for literally generations, this fan isn't too loud for me, produces 3 options that are all useful (low sleeping, high working out) in between cheap and pricy and works better than the over priced ones. It's a win. As long as it's around I will never want another fan.

Title: Lasko makes unbeatable fans and this unit is no exception.
Review Content: I have purchased two of these superb floor fans. They have the high flow rate of a big box fan yet are controllable like a smaller unit. You can't beat Lasko fans in residential applications. I used to be a fan (pun intended) of the "H" branded fans but, in my opinion, they have dramatically deteriorated in quality over time, feeling like they are manufactured to a price point. Two of that brand's fans have had their stand break on me over the past 5 years. This great Lasko fan puts out tremendous volume. It is not, however, a high velocity fan. Too much emphasis is placed on speed, I believe. It is volume that matters in most instances and this unit puts it out in spades. My only suggestion for improvement involves the friction knobs holding the orientation of the fan. If you move the angle of the fan up or down without loosening the knobs first, they have a tendency to either self-tighten or loosen depending on the direction you rotate the fan head. This forces you to loosen and then tighten the knobs every time you want to move the fan up or down. It isn't a big deal and not enough to knock the review score down. Very recommended.

Title: If you want to move a lot of air very quietly this is your ticket!

Both of these running together are quieter than a single older fan that I had been using!So with these two fans running And the temperature outside being in the mid teens It keeps the kitchen family room area Between 72 degrees and about 77 degrees And the other end of the house at about 68 degrees.during the days I have been doing this our air to air heat pump has not had to turn on! especially since that these outside temperatures air to air heat pumps are terribly inefficient and might even throw you over to the extremely high cost Emergency electric and heaters!

Title: My favorite fan -- ever.
Review Content: I just bought TWO to replace the ONE my father gave me in 2017 that finally died last summer (2023). There IS no better non-oscillating fan, in my opinion. I only add the non-oscillating part because my husband sleeps with one of those fans that goes back and forth, and after years of The Great Fan Debate we've just decided they're totally separate categories.Here's why this one is the best;1. It's a serious trooper. My parents had theirs for years before they gave it to ME. Then it performed flawlessly even when moved frequently and used OFTEN. The ONLY reason it finally died was harassment from a truly demented Siamese cat moving at high speed doing things the manufacturer NEVER intended. Just...trust me on this.2. The air flow is AMAZING. It moves so much air so evenly that I STILL say it makes oscillating just plain unnecessary, and that's on "low". I put this in a room at one end of the house and push air through from one end of the house to the other, steadily but unobtrusively on the ground floor. The 2nd fan is upstairs (one very large bedroom).3. The versatility is stupendous. You can mount it on a wall, or you can almost effortlessly just pick it up and put it in any room. It tilts and stays precisely at the angle you put it at.Like most larger fans, it takes a bit of time to take it apart and clean it. No, not my favorite chore, BUT I honestly don't see how they could make it easier to take apart to clean without sacrificing the durability. And I'd rather have these fans that will last a LONG time (said Siamese cat has found other obsessions) than one of my husband's easier to clean fans that MAYBE last 2 years before they start to wobble or just break.They're not silent, but I really don't care. On "low" it's not much louder than a house fan, heat, or a/c, and the only times I've  turned it on medium or high were to just SKIP a/c during a heat wave or dry a shampooed carpet. Yup, it moves enough air for THAT.

Title: Works great, difficult to clean
Review Content: Works great, very powerful. But difficult to clean.  Dust will cling to the blades, and you can't blow the dust off with canned air, and you can't get a swiffer or duster device in through the crevices.  Traditional box fans are easy to remove the grille and clean the blades manually.  You can't do that with this one.  They should be built with the ability to remove the grilles.

Title: Excellent Replacement for Old Cyclone Fan
Review Content: We have a great, dependable Lasko Cyclone fan that has served us well for about 20 years now. I recently bought another one from Home Depot to put in another room of our home, and holy moly was I disappointed in the quality! The plastic is cheaper and flimsier, it doesn't move as much air, and it wobbles right out of the box. I took it back and decided to give their Wind Machine model a try instead, which is even priced nearly the same as the Cyclone. The Wind Machine is a FAR superior fan in almost every way. No wobble, build quality is better, no clicky detent during pivot, and it moves air very well like my old Cyclone. Lasko, what are you doing making two nearly identical fans at the same price, and one is significantly higher quality than the other. Buy the Wind Machine and don't look back.

Title: A good air mover
Review Content: It came fully assembled with no packing material so I assume I got a used fan and not a new one. It looked to be in excellent shape. The person who assembled it saved me some work. It moves a lot of air even on the lowest setting. I really like that you can tilt it so as to make the fans face into a cooling table. In the near constant 99° heat electronics don't do very well. Turn the fans face facing straight up and place your phone and/or tablet on it. Use something small near the devices edges so air can circulate better around them.  It'll take two such items for tablets and one for a phone. These really are great fans and I highly recommend them.Not only is it light weight, I'd say it's almost too light. It is as large as I was afraid it would be, but still can sit atop my 1200 watt microwave box (knew I kept that for a reason). All that was required to get it up and running was pull it out of it's box, set it on top of the microwave box, plug it in to a 10 guage extension cable and turn it on. It is quiet on the lowest setting. The noise atthe 2nd setting doubles and on the 3rd is 50% more still. Not at all bad. The air flow is gentle on the 1st setting, but still the fan is moving a good amount of air; enough to keep me cool in 98° heat with no AC. When the temps crawl to 100 and above will update you on how it does (that is if I survive).

Title: “The Tornado Whisperer"
Review Content: Listen up, fellows! I’ve discovered the eighth wonder of the world, and it’s not the Hanging Gardens of Babylon or the Great Wall of China. No, my friends, it’s the Lasko Wind Machine Air Circulator Floor Fan!Gale-Force Breezes and Dramatic Hair Flips:This fan doesn’t just blow air; it orchestrates a symphony of wind. I turned it on, and suddenly my living room felt like the set of a blockbuster movie. Curtains billowed, papers flew, and my hair did a sassy dance. I half-expected a director to yell, “Cut! That’s a wrap!” Powered by Unicorn Whispers:I’m convinced this fan runs on unicorn whispers. When it spins, I hear faint giggles and the distant sound of rainbows. And let’s not forget the mystical breeze—it’s like a gentle hug from a mythical creature. Fan Parties Are the New Rage:I’ve started hosting Lasko Wind Machine fan parties. Guests arrive, and we all gather around the fan, chanting, “Blow, baby, blow!” We’ve even given it a name: Sir Whirlwind McZephyr. He’s the life of the party, spinning tales of distant lands and lost socks.No Tangles, No Drama:Other fans? Pfft. They tangle up like spaghetti in a blender. But not this one. It’s like it has a PhD in untangling itself. I’ve watched it perform acrobatics—loop-de-loops, figure eights—without breaking a sweat. It’s the Cirque du Soleil of cables. Inhale the Wind, Exhale the Joy:So, if you want a fan that’s more than a fan, get yourself the Lasko Wind Machine Air Circulator Floor Fan. It’s a breeze of joy, a cyclone of happiness, and a whirlwind of delight. Plus, it doubles as a makeshift wind turbine for your dreams.Happy twirling, my fellow wind dancers!

Title: Nice 20” fan for both cooling and white noise!
Review Content: As other reviewers had experienced, the first fan arrived with some minor damage.  In this case there was a small piece broken underneath the top handle, plus the handle itself was not properly set, likely related to the minor damage.  There was also some mysterious reddish stains just before one of the blue side tension knobs(?).  I requested a replacement/identical Lasko fan be shipped, while I returned this one.The second and current fan arrived in fine shape, and is working well without any issues.  The pictures I’ve included show the comparisons of the two mentioned areas between the returned fan and the current fan.This fan is replacing our decade old Lasko 20” fan, and so far sounds noticeably quieter, yet with equal wind output.  I would recommend this product.

Title: Best in Price Range
Review Content: Who doesn't love a Lasko Wind Machine?  You've probably seen them around and didn't even notice.  These bad boys put out some serious air.  Circulators are more than just a fan; they're meant to move a volume of air around a room, equalizing the temperature and eliminating warm spots (or even cold spots.  Put it on low and point up to move the heat off the ceiling and around the room).  Anyways if you plan to use it outside, get a fan.  Blow it on you.  yippee.  But if you plan to use it inside, get this and understand that it doesn't have to be pointed at you to make the room more comfortable.  Place it strategically to create a current of air flow around the room.

Title: Second Time Buying
Review Content: We love this fan. It’s lightweight but sturdy and packs a big punch! I love that it can tilt to adjust the airflow. I’m sure our first one would have lasted longer (I’ve had it for a LONG time), but it really gets thrown around, put in places it shouldn’t be, or gets shoved up against something so there isn’t adequate space behind it. We have used this in multiple houses and taken it camping in our camper many times. It runs 24/7. We like the “white noise” sound (and circulation) while sleeping. It isn’t loud (can easily hear the tv above it), but gives just the right level of noise. It has a handle on the top for easy transport.Update: CLEARLY not the same fan we had previously. It looks exactly the same, but this one has a knob in the back to turn on/off instead of buttons on the top. I didn’t care, because I didn’t love the light on top of the last one. However, the knob fell off after a week! We can get it back on, but just barely enough to turn on/off, then it falls off again. This version is much more poorly made than our previous version!

Title: Update: So far, so good
Review Content: I REALLY wanted to like this fan.  It's a good size---unlike those "camping" fans, which are TOO SMALL---and it runs very quietly.  I used it just a couple of times (I think I had it plugged in then), and stored it away in my bedroom for a few years.  So, wanting to use it again for the hurricane season, I took it out and installed new batteries, but I find that it ONLY works when plugged in!  Unfortunately, I need it for power outages, so will have to buy a new fan.  I agree with other reviewers that the switch seems cheaply made, but I didn't care about that as long it worked---but it doesn't!---not on batteries.  It ought to work---i did put the screws back in the battery compartment, and tightened them.  Still nothing!  If you need a fan to keep you alive during a power outage, you'll have to look elsewhere.Update:  Encouraged by the fact that many others seem to have received a fully functional fan, I took a chance and ordered a new 10-inch Treva fan to replace the one I got in 2020.  I installed new batteries (ordered fromAmazon) and tightened the screws.  Yes!  It runs, and on both speeds.  Let's see if it lasts through the hurricane season.  I'm giving it four stars provisionally.  I bought this fanfor use during power outages, so it'sessential that it run on batteries.

Title: Great quality fan, quiet, durable, lightweight, and excellent battery life!
Review Content: I was looking for a small fan that was portable, light weight, and battery operated with plug in, and I finally found it. I just love this fan! It is so quiet and puts out just the right amount of airflow, with 2 speed options. I use it mainly in my bathroom, but have also used it while watching TV, and it's so quiet that it doesn't interfere with that. Plus, I love the light weight of it because it makes it so easy to carry and place it wherever I want to. I also love that I can put it close to me when I'm having a hot flash, so it cools me down quickly. I am just so very pleased with everything about it. It's still going strong on the D batteries I put in it a month ago, which is awesome! Definitely will be buying another one!

Title: Strong airflow, great for power outages
Review Content: A power outage in the height of Texas summer is just about the worst thing that can happen.  During one that lasted several hours, I ended up driving across town and taking my elderly dog shopping, just to get her inside somewhere that had a/c.  More recently, we've had some short power outages, lasting maybe an hour each.  Still, that's enough time for my apartment to go from slightly-warmer-than-I'd-like to my-living-room-is-a-burning-hell.  Looking for a back-up plan, I decided to see if battery operated fans were even a thing, and that's when I found this O2Cool fan.  I was a little nervous about buying it, since a few reviewers said theirs didn't work or didn't last, but a few reviews from hurricane areas had me wanting to give it a try.  So I ordered one and crossed my fingers.TL;DR: Awesome fan, works great!First off, I like the size and design.  This isn't one of those tiny palm-sized USB fans; it's about a foot wide in total, with a 10" span inside for the actual fan blades.  It's slightly taller than it is wide, but it's depth is pretty compact.  The vented cover is sized just right for me to not accidentally slip a finger inside when I pick it up, though it does have a carrying handle if you want to play it really safe.  It does come with an A/C adapter, which I guess is nice, but I don't really need.  Then again, it may come in handy if one of my two regular fans goes out and I need a temporary replacement.It's kind of a battery hog in that it needs 6 D-batteries to run, but honestly, I think that's a good thing.  Any less, and it'd be a much smaller, weaker fan that wouldn't last any time at all.  I haven't had occasion to run it for hours and hours and hours, but according to other customers, it lasts 9+ hours on high and even longer on low.  I think that will be plenty to get me through the next power outage.  And about those low and high speeds... This thing has great air flow.  I wouldn't want to set it up 10 feet away from me, but since it's not tied to a cord or outlet, that won't be a problem.  On low speed, there's plenty of air flow, and on high speed, it's awesome.  It's slightly less powerful than the 22" corded turbo fans I use on a daily basis.All in all, I'd say this is an awesome buy.  I was impressed enough with the first one that I immediately ordered a second, and both work very well with both the A/C adapter and batteries.  I'm stocked up on D batteries now, too, so it looks like I'm set to ride out the next power outage in comfort!Update 12/1/2108:  I bought two of these fans to get me through a power outage, which hasn't happened yet.  But a few weeks ago, my apartment's a/c went out in the middle of the night, and the two fans I brought into the bedroom just weren't enough.  I ended up grabbing one of these battery operated fans, intending to use the included A/C cord, and set it up on my nightstand.  But in my sleepy, overheated stupor, I turned it on and quickly fell asleep -- forgetting to plug it in.  Six hours later, I woke up and called maintenance, and they had my a/c fixed fast.  Then I went to unplug and put away this fan, only to realize I'd left it running on high for 6 hours on nothing but battery power!  So yes, I can now say without a doubt that these little fans run great for at least several hours.Update: Here I am. Power outage. Texas. Summer. While my neighbors sit in their doorways trying to catch a weak breeze, my dog and I are comfortably lounging on the sofa, a fan trained on each of us, while she sleeps and I read my Kindle. This is EXACTLY the scenario I wanted to be prepared for, and these fans are everything I'd hoped for!

Title: Long Lasting
Review Content: I purchased this fan in August of 2018 for travel and emergencies. It’s not the most compact fan, but I have flown with it several times and it saved me. This is also my fan for power outages. It gives me the noise I need for sleep if the power goes out at night. I was without power for about 48 hours from hurricane Helene. It was hot in our house, but I stayed cool by laying in front of this fan pretty much the whole time. You can get about a full 24 hours on one set of batteries (it takes 6 Ds). The fan will still work, but the output lessens as the batteries drain. The noise is still good for sleep, but you’ll need to swap them out to remain cool. We have other battery operated fans that I don’t like as much, and they take 8 batteries. If you have batteries in the fan, it won’t run on a cord. This fan only takes 6, and it will run off of the power cord even if it has batteries in it. It has been good for 6 years, so I’m purchasing another one. Definitely a great purchase!

Title: Runs on D cell batteries or plugged into AC
Review Content: Have this fan mostly for power or AC outage (just in case).  Would be suitable for camping or a little picnicking breeze on a warm day.I also own a USB-rechargeable fan, but wanted a this fan too where I can use regular store-bought batteries as, at some point, in an outage, recharging the USB might not be an easy option anymore (can recharge my power bank with my car but that is slow).  I keep a few extra D cell batteries beyond the 6 required for the fan.  (Tip: To help the batteries last longer, don't store them in the fan when not needed.)A hot day/night with no air circulation is very uncomfortable.  There are other solutions, but for the money, this fan definitely helps.

Title: Deserves a review
Review Content: i usually don’t write reviews good or bad but I have to with this product. I needed battery powered + a/c portable fans for the 2 hurricanes we had in Florida. Happy to say the power was only out for 5 hours overnight and this fan came in handy keeping me cool for a few hours of sleep. Lately the weather has been cool at night and I put the fan by the window to save on a/c costs. I noticed the fan would only run on low but stopped on the high setting. I sent an email to the company and explained my concerns and received an answer in 2 hours telling me a refund would show up in my Amazon account. Later that same evening Amazon notified me of the refund. The customer service from Treva is outstanding and will definitely buy from them in the future.

Title: Perfect for dorms or offices on top of Desktops.
Review Content: I have been using this fan since December 2014 and it has been perfect. I originally bought this fan to use in my dorm because last semsester (fall 2014) the ac in my (low cost / old) dorm stopped blowing cool/cold air. It only blew out very hot air. I was left to the mercy of the university to send someone out to fix since we are not allowed to mess with at all. That person never came so rather than allow the hot air to blow and bake me to death, I just had to completely shut it off ( my dorm still uses individual ac units that are attached to the windows lol )  but doing so just leaves the air very stuffy and basically zero circulation in my room. That's why I bought this, sorry if it is too much but I feel it demonstrates what I was looking for in a fan when I went shopping on amazon for one.here are the pro's and conspros:Size is perfect for sitting on a desktop in the corner. I can set it in the corner and be able to utilize my desktop for either my laptop or for Home Work.To my amazement this little fan blows air very well. It has two settings for how hard it blows air. the lowest is usually enough for me since I have facing towards my face on my desktop but even on the highest I don't get that feeling of being smacked in the face by the air.It isn't "weak" but it isn't powerful like an industrial fan. If need a heavy duty fan then buy an industrial one. I obviously don't need such a large fan in my dorm and doubt it would even be allowed.Fairly quiet and sound isn't annoying. I find it soothing when my dorm room is completely silent.I use the adapter and don't really use the batteries because I leave it on almost all day 24/7. So I am able to tell you how long it lasts on batteries but it requires 4 D batteries so it should last a decent amount.Cons:nonewill keep review updated on status on my fan or if it ever "goes out".The price on this is very reasonable. I didn't want a complicated / high-tech fan that had tons of settings. I just wanted something simple but functional and durable. Looking at the reviews on amazon I decided this O2COOL fan W/adapter was just what I was looking for.

Title: Got me through extended power outage.

I use them on the lower speed to conserve battery life. They cool sufficiently and are fairly quiet. Be sure you have plenty of D batteries on hand.

Title: Acceptable but could be improved
Review Content: Pretty good fan. I take it with me to league night bowling as it tends to get pretty stuffy in there. On high it has plenty of air flow to keep my grip hand and face dry.Con 1: Eats batteries really fast on high. I solved this in a round-about way. Rather than using lower voltage rechargeable NiMH batteries, I used a USB battery pack (10.5Ah@5V) capable of delivering 2.1A and a 5V to 9V converter to use for the power input port (a standard 2.1 x 5.5mm barrel connector). When I tried to run it straight, it would not run the fan on high speed. After adding a 47µF capacitor to the boost converter output to counteract the inductive load of the motor, it ran just fine. Seems to be supplying about 900mA at 9V to the fan on high, which is strange given that the supplied AC adapter is only rated to supply 700mA. Using this improvised external battery, the fan does seem to push more air than it did with fresh copper-top D-cell batteries. I suppose that makes sense with power loss and voltage sag of alkaline cells nearing 1A of current draw. I think it would be a much better design if they used some 18650 or 26650 lithium ion batteries that users could swap out on occasion. Alkaline cells just aren't a good choice for high current draw applications like this. Even NiMH batteries would be acceptable if you could use 8 of them to keep the voltage around 9V.Con 2: The switch is incredibly easy to switch. Too easy, in fact. If you leave it somewhere where it can be wiggled any (like, say, a car), it is really easy for the switch to be flipped on just by the fan rubbing against something else.Con 3: I don't like the angle that the fan points. As it is right now, it generally points at my chest while I would like it better if it pointed more upward to keep my face dry. Which means that I either have to duck like I'm hiding from someone or grab the fan and hold it tilted back. I'm 1.8m tall (5'11") for reference.Other than those gripes, this fan has worked pretty solid for me for several months now.

As it is right now, it generally points at my chest while I would like it better if it pointed more upward to keep my face dry. Which means that I either have to duck like I'm hiding from someone or grab the fan and hold it tilted back. I'm 1.8m tall (5'11") for reference.Other than those gripes, this fan has worked pretty solid for me for several months now.

Title: Very thin design, though not as quiet as others
Review Content: If having a narrow platform is your primary concern, this is one of the thinnest fan designs that you will find. However, the sound it makes is mildly annoying and not nearly as quiet as the similarly sized Vornado.  I ended up getting two Vornado 573 circulators instead as they are significantly quieter.

Title: Great for traveling & cruising
Review Content: I've never used batteries with it so I can't speak to battery life, but this thing is light weight, flat, and blows just enough air to keep me cool at night in bed or after the shower. I love that it's DC powered so the plug works with both US and European voltages (110-220) - no need for a power converter (Just an adapter if you don't already have one).This fan has been all around the world with me for a few years now and is still working just fine. Its flatness makes it suitable for easy packing in your luggage and it even fits in a backpack if your luggage is a little full. I travel often and take it on every trip.It's not loud so don't expect it to double as a noise machine.

Title: Two Fans ran for 9 HOURS on batteries !!!
Review Content: Ran for 9 HOURS on batteries !!!  I got two of these units for an outdoor event.  I brought a bunch of D batteries assuming this thing was just going to blow through them ( no fan could run for 8 hours, right ?! ).  I initially did what the directions said and ran both fans on low, but within 30 minutes of turning them on, my wife set them on High.  We were under a popup tent for an event, on a concrete street in 95 degrees Florida heat.  After a few hours, we just forgot they were running on batteries, and random people were popping in our tent to steal some air from our fan ( ha ha ).  Then at the end of the event, I realized we never switched the batteries, and these freaking fans had run non-stop for NINE HOURS.  Both of them, without flaw.Needless to say, these are going with us from now on.  I am super impressed, even more so by what happened the next day.  So we got these units home and I took the batteries out of them and ended up putting one next to my bed to run at night since they had a nice breeze.  I had this fan plugged in.Around 10 AM the power went out because of a storm, but this fan kept on running for 5 minutes.  I was confused since the batteries were out, and I had no idea how the fan could still be running.  Turns out the fan is so efficient that it was literally running off the stored charge in the capacitor in the power brick that the unit uses for power.I honestly can't get over how impressive that is.  NO BATTERIES.  NO POWER.  And the thing still ran for 5 minutes just off the stored charge in the power brick that was plugged into the outlet... even though everything else in my house was dead !!!

Title: Hurricane prep must have
Review Content: If you like in Florida, I highly recommend these! They are portable, durable and great if you lose power. Price is great for value.
Manually Corrected Review Content: If you like in Florida, I highly recommend these! They are portable, durable and great if you lose power. Price is great for value.

Title: Good little fan
Review Content: It's a pretty good little fan, and I've got no complaints for the $20 price.  A very necessary item for camping or hiking during hot and humid summer days, when you can't always count on a breeze when you want it.  Also makes a rather quiet and conveniently sized fan around your home, car, or office (I've often been annoyed that 120V box fans are so loud, even on their LOW setting).  And an important bit of emergency preparedness, providing just a little bit of airflow and cooling in event of grid power failing during hot summer days (hope you've got LOTS of fully-charged D batteries lying around, or a spare car battery!).On LOW it's pretty quiet, about as loud as a ceiling fan (UPDATE: after two years of light use, the motor has become significantly noisier, much like a card in bicycle spokes).  If you're sensitive to noise, it might bother you just a little bit trying to sleep in-front of it.  But when you really need it, you probably won't complain...My only objection is the two screws you have to lighten/loosen to change the batteries.  A bit of hassle, that could have been avoided.  I wish they had used some other method to hold the batteries securely that didn't require the extra time and tools.I am happy to see that the AC adapter is 12V (which is very common), even though the 6xD batteries will only provide about half that, requiring more circuitry within the fan.  It runs noticeably faster and louder on 12V than on batteries, but nothing dramatic.  I also love that the outlet/receptacle on the fan accepts BOTH of the two most common type of DC barrel plugs, making a good connection with either, so a couple of car/cig adapters I've already got laying around work just perfectly with this fan.Specs on AC/DC wall-wart:Switching AdapterMODEL:SUN-1200070INPUT:100-240V~ 50/60Hz 0.05AOUTPUT:12V --- 0.7A (positive center polarity)Measured power consumption:LOW:  5WHIGH: 9WPF:  .51The electronics near the plug (presumably the voltage regulator) gets noticeably warm during operation on wall or car power (but not on battery power).  But after a several hours, it still seems to be staying only just slightly warm, so no worries, but it might have been a bit more efficient with a different design.UPDATE:  Be careful about ordering this fan.  From several user comments, it sounds like the fan might have been significantly redesigned recently, OR perhaps one (or more) of the sellers here could be passing off a different and wrong product.  Be aware.

Title: New Fan works UPDATE:  D batteries
Review Content: I bought Rayovac D batteries for this fan.  The lid to the battery compartment would not close.  It did close if I removed the batteries.  I thought maybe a different brand of battery might fit, but I read that another commenter could not get the Amazon D batteries to fit, either.  Since other commenters had no problems, I am assuming that something is wrong with this particular fan and am returning it.  It is a nice, quiet, elegant fan.  I would keep it except that I need a battery-operated fan as a backup for hurricane season.UPDATE:  I returned the fan and ordered another fan that was USED from Amazon Warehouse.  It arrived with the D batteries installed.  I opened and closed the battery compartment without any difficulties.  Then I removed the batteries and installed the Rayovac batteries that I had at home.  Again, the lid to the battery compartment operated perfectly.  No problems.The fan has been running on "High" using battery power for the past 15-16 hours.  I just ordered another Treva fan so that I will have two Treva fans if we have a power outage here in Houston.I gave this fan a total four-star review because of the problems that I experienced with the first defective fan, to which I gave 1 star.  I returned it and have since acquired two fans that work properly.  I would give them 5 stars.

Title: Like it
Review Content: I was looking for a medium sized fan that took batteries to replace an old one in my hurricane supply stash, and this one is perfect. It’s a good personal size, can run on power if available and on replaceable batteries if power is out, no need to find a source of power to recharge it. It is not expensive and appears to be of good quality. It was just what I was looking for, and not easy to find a personal fan that did not have a rechargeable battery.

Title: Perfect

Title: Used Once my 1st review, 2nd use not good
Review Content: Can't wait to use.  Will update when I do.  The AC adapter power was exactly the same as battery power.2018 - We had no electricity to use for A/C or fan, so this was what we used.  Fortunately the weather at night was in the 55-60ish range.  This fan ran for 3 nights at about 8 hours each and about 4 hours during the day.  A total of 28 hours.  It is still going.  I have to say this MODEL is much better than a Coleman I had.  My Coleman took 6-8 D cell batteries and barely lasted 8 hours.  And I ran it on high and low settings.  It still has power to run!!!Also I used the AC adapter when I got it to compare it to the battery power.  NO DIFFERENCE.  LOVE this fan.2019 - Had stored the fan without the batteries, over the winter.  Our annual boondocking trip was coming up, so I put in the OLD batteries, still had juice and ran fine.  Get to our location in WI and no electric, which we knew, hence the fan.  So get it out and put in OLD batteries, it ran for about 10 seconds and then faded, then would rev up, then fade to off, then rev up, and kept doing this up and down and when it was running it wasn't much a a breeze.  Purchased NEW 18.00 batteries D and put those in.  SAME THING!  So this year it was much hotter than last year, we were miserable.  I'm sure they won't take this back, we've had it for a year and used it 4 days.  I am soooooo disappointed.  The first use of the fan was fine.  Hope others don't have this issue.  If you do and solved it please let me know how.

Title: O2COOL NEW 10" Battery Operated Fan with Adapter GOOD NEWS/BAD NEWS
Review Content: O2COOL NEW 10" Battery Operated Fan with AdapterGOOD NEWS/BAD NEWSI have owned two of these fans bought on the same order about five weeks ago.First,the good news. One fan operates very quietly(probably because of the fanblades size and pitch) and with respectable outputfor the size motor it has. This fan operates well on ALKALINE  batteries,but I use it primarilyin a bedroom on AC power.Now for the bad. the "other fan in my order has at times been nothing but frustrating. there were timesthat it would not operate at all via battery OR AC power. then I shook it a bit and voila,it started working.well,what good does that do you. As I had to see if there was anything wrong I could see,I separated thegrill halves from each other(oh no! my warranty!!). after following the wiring to the motor,it was easy tospot the fact that one of the wires at its terminal was either cold soldered at some point and when I saw it,it was disconnected altogether. wow,nice quality control. I figured,well ,ok I will just solder it properly andcall it good.Then,even as the fan was "working",it became extremely noisy and bothersome. It sounds a bit likecrickets chirping,but really annoying ones. I did a fit check and the fan blades came nowhere nearanything,and I could not see any interference anywhere,so that was a dead end. I don't know if it is bearing noise or what. I am done playing around with it. I use it when I have to,but thats about it. strangely,from time to time,it straightens out and it isquiet as my first fan is,for a limited time. its hit or miss when you start it up,you never know what your goingto get at any one time during its operation. stupid me,I threw out the boxes they came in,and hate sending back junk anyway,its just a pain for me to have to do. SO,I would say the fan that works well,i would give it five stars ,however,the one that has the quirks and needed soldering,and still makes a racket,I hate it and would give it maybe one star. I can see if there was some design flaw,but as for the crappy soldering job at the "factory",really WEEEEEAK.

Title: Great Little Fan
Review Content: I didn't even know there was such a thing as battery operated fans until Hurricane Helene passed through my town. I have to sleep with the white noise a fan provides so spent a sleepless night until a neighbor loaned me hers.  As soon as our power was restored, I ordered this one. It's not as loud as I prefer but it's great with moving air around in hot & humid weather and provides enough sound to allow me to get some sleep. Thinking about ordering a few more to place in different rooms, what a great addition to my home.

Title: Indispensable
Review Content: I can't sleep without a fan. Recently we had a "derecho" and no power for five days. This fan made my life worth living. I liked it soMuch I bought a second. It is cheaper on Amazon than the local Store. As are the batteries. Aren't batteries insanely expensive anymore? Buy the fan and the D cells at the same time. Have the ready with a battery operated lantern for the next power outage. It won't save your food but you will be more Comfortable with some air moving. And you can take the fan ANYWHERE!! Who doesn't need a fan?? They're a delight! I put the batteries in and turned it on and my dog plopped down and soaked up the moving air. Between you and me the second fan was for him. One for me and one for the dog. It even has lights!! So you have moving air and you won't trip Over the shoes you forgot were in the middle of the floor before the power went out. Or the sticks at the campsite. I don't know what you're tripping over but this will make you happier while you're doing it. It's very lightweight. Most of the weight is from the batteries to be honest

Title: Cool for the Summer
Review Content: My room is always so hot because I live in West Texas where it's always dry. My air conditioning isn't the best and most other rooms in the house are usually pretty cool because they get ventilated pretty well, but my room is always uncomfortablely warm, even with a window down. I'm always sweating like crazy whenever I spend more than 15 minutes in my room. This fan is a perfect size, not too huge and small enough to place somewhere on a desk or on top of a shelf. It has a low speed setting and high speed. The low speed is whisper quiet and provides a surprisingly good amount of air. The high speed will reach all the way across my room, about 15 feet, and I can steel feel the breeze pretty well. I leave it on my desk so I can stay cool while doing homework on my laptop, and it still reaches across the room to my bed so that way I can still feel cool while I'm asleep. Only downside to the high speed is that its fairly loud, but having it on in the background for a while you will get used to the sound and it starts to just sound like white noise. Also, you can either use it plugged in with an outlet, or take it with you anywhere as there is a battery compartment  on the back, which I have  yet to test out. The fan is also very light and fairly slim, so moving it around isnt a problem. The only thing I was unaware of until I took it out of the box is that the back of the fan is a white/grayish color, despite the front of the fan being black. There might be pictures of this on here that show this, I just didn't notice until I saw the fan for myself. Also, the cord that connects the fan to an outlet is shorter than I expected, only about 4 feet, but this is no problem with an extension cord. Overall though, it's a great fan and keeps me cool throughout the day.

Title: GREAT FOR POWER OUTTAGES
Review Content: I HAVE 2 OF THESE THAT I USED IN THE PHILIPPINES FOR MONTHS AFTER HURRICANE ODETTE DEVASTATED THE AREA. WE HAD NO POWER FOR 7 MONTHS, YES 7. THESE FANS USING D BATTERIES WERE LIFESAVING. WE HAD TO SLEEP OUTSIDE UNDER MOSQUITO NETTING FOR MONTHS AND THESE FANS WERE GREAT. THEY LAST A DECENT AMOUNT OF TIME ON 6 OR 8 (I FORGET EXACTLY) D BATTERIES. MY ONLY MINOR COMPLAINT IS THAT THE BATTERY DOOR IS A LITTLE DIFFICULT TO OPEN AND CLOSE BUT IF YOU ARE CAREFUL AND GENTLE IT WORKS FINE. IT USES LITTLE SCREWS TO HOLD THE BATTERY DOOR ON BUT I JUST LEFT THEM OUT AND TAPED THEM TO THE SIDE OF THE FAN IN CASE I NEEDED THEM LATER. THE DOOR ITSELF ACTS AS THE CONNECTOR TO MAKE THE BATTERIES WORK, SIMILAR TO A FLASHLIGHT. ANYWAY, IT WORKS FINE AND I BOUGHT 2 MORE JUST IN CASE. THESE ARE THE BEST BATTERY FANS OUT THERE.

MY ONLY MINOR COMPLAINT IS THAT THE BATTERY DOOR IS A LITTLE DIFFICULT TO OPEN AND CLOSE BUT IF YOU ARE CAREFUL AND GENTLE IT WORKS FINE. IT USES LITTLE SCREWS TO HOLD THE BATTERY DOOR ON BUT I JUST LEFT THEM OUT AND TAPED THEM TO THE SIDE OF THE FAN IN CASE I NEEDED THEM LATER. THE DOOR ITSELF ACTS AS THE CONNECTOR TO MAKE THE BATTERIES WORK, SIMILAR TO A FLASHLIGHT. ANYWAY, IT WORKS FINE AND I BOUGHT 2 MORE JUST IN CASE. THESE ARE THE BEST BATTERY FANS OUT THERE.

Title: Great when you don't have power
Review Content: We lost power for almost three days in the middle of the summer... 80 plus degree nights.  We had bought one of these the last time that happened years ago and were so pleased with the performance we bought another.  The fan made it possible for us to sleep during those nights.  Highly recommended.

Title: Quiet and dont use a lot of power. Good for off grid and tent camping.
Review Content: These use 1/4 the power of a regular size box fan and are much quieter.  We also  take them camping and run them over night off of a jackery type solar battery.

Title: Fantastic powerful dual-power personal-size fan
Review Content: I first bought this fan two months ago at our local Ace Hardware when I was looking for a dual-powered fan for impending planned “Public Safety Power Shutoffs” because of high firestorm danger. I LOVED it so much I bought four more on Amazon since the hardware store was out of stock (one as a gift for my daughter in NC in hurricane season and two each for my house and my dad’s house.) In conjunction with wet washcloths, using this fan I was able to sleep when the interior temperature of our house was over 100 degrees. This little fan has a very small thin profile and is extremely light, but powerful. I often feel hot so I keep at least one on the dining table and one on the bedside table. I use them plugged in when we have power. But when the power was turned off I was so pleased that I didn’t need to use the batteries as it worked on my little $99 CAT power station that I had also purchased in preparation for power outages. But when I need the battery power, this fan can go anywhere without having to worry about finding an electric outlet. Both speeds are very quiet! Two times the cord was stepped on and the fan was pulled off the desk to a carpeted floor and the fan was not damaged in the least. I’ve only had one issue with one fan - it developed a little bit of a rattle shortly after receiving it. Not bad, but a little annoying. Interestingly if I rotate the fan 90 or 180 degrees the rattle disappears, but unfortunately the shape of the fan doesn’t permit setting it on its side or upside down. Other than this one issue I am very happy with this fan and highly recommend it!

Title: Mine seems to be a used product.
Review Content: I noticed some scuffing in various places around the fan, with one of them looking a little burnt or dirty. The cover of the section that houses batteries, which is on the bottom back of the fan, when screwed in all the way isn't flush with the bottom of the fan, though after looking through reviews with pictures, I notice others may have this issue as well so it might just be how it's made. It doesn't appear to have trouble standing because of this, but I still felt a bit disappointed with the scuffing and also with how cheap and wonky it feels because of that not-flush battery cover.I don't have a problem with used items that work fine, but I paid for a new one. I was able to speak with Customer Service and in my case, I kept the item and got a partial refund since like I said, it obviously works fine—but it seemed visibly used. I just hope any prior owner took ok care with the fan and it won't just break down in a short while. After speaking with Customer Service, I looked through the reviews more in-depth to see if I was possibly wrong and apparently a bunch of people have gotten USED fans with varying degrees of obviousness. One guy also mentioned he got two fans, one of them was used and the other was actually shrink-wrapped. Mine was not shrink-wrapped.Performance-wise, it seems fine. Two speeds, noise doesn't bother me and I'm one of those people who is mildly driven crazy by loud fans. It's not heavy duty, and the whole thing is plastic so if you're looking for durability, you probably won't be a FAN of this product. But it will work for boring office desk use or even small rooms. The plastic body does make it very light, so that is potentially good for portability but it does seems like it is liable to break with medium force, like if you dropped it or someone dropped something on it. I appreciate its slim build as someone who lives in a house with annoyingly narrow window ledges (the kind that you try to put plant pots in and then are annoyed because if only they were 0.5" wider they would fit, etc.) so that's really a major plus about it. Also I find it not super ugly or as typically generic looking for a plastic fan, for those of you who also wanted to buy one of those cool looking vintage fans but couldn't justify dropping $75+ on it.

Title: They could help survive a power outage on a hot day/night!
Review Content: These fans, we bought 2, have all the attributes needed to survive times without power.  We have a large fan for the common area and these 2, one for each bedroom.  We have tried them, both plugged in and running on batteries, and they seem fine, a definite relief in smaller rooms.  They are now in our "emergency closet"... one that is centrally located in the house.  A list is taped to the inside of the door noting everything enclosed.  I hope this helps.  I will write again after their use... which I hope isn't soon.  Fingers crossed they receive good marks after their test, I do expect they will.  Good luck!

Title: Portable
Review Content: This fan is perfect for taking on a cruise . Fits perfectly in my check-in suitcase. Powerful.
Manually Corrected Review Content: This fan is perfect for taking on a cruise . Fits perfectly in my check-in suitcase. Powerful.

Title: Not as Good as it Once Was
Review Content: I owned one of these from years back, same size, same maker.  This is Virtually the same model but  the batteries inserted differently.  TO ME, its seems the power and breeze is not nearly as strong as the one I previously owned (Has two speeds low and high), the one I owned prior could easily run 6+ hours on battery only with some slowing in the final hour..  But still, it runs VERY quietly, in fact if you have a TV or radio on normal or less volume you might not even note it was on minus the breeze.  And during summer/power outage thunderstorm season these are MUST HAVES as who wants to sit in STUFFY while waiting on the power company.  Just put a bowl of ice in front of it and mini a/c on batteries. Would be great for camping, porches-keeping bugs off you etc.  I cannot speak for how long this will run on battery life as I just got and have it on DC power. Tested with Batteries and runs fine BUT slower than previous design. If you lose the back, you lose your battery power ability, I do not like that compared to the older model, poor and cheap design as backs DO get lost over time on portable items.  It comes with two tiny little Philips type screws with springs, VERY annoying and unless you are going camping, you really do not have to use them.  The back can be fussy to put back on once batteries are in and has that cheap, easily breakable feel-for that  3 stars, the older model was 5 stars. Will about slice your fingers trying  to get them started. Cheap. Otherwise the fan is exactly the same as it's older predecessor. But despite my 3 stars I will probably get another, its nice looking and who can beat a battery operated fan this size.  Do not let my 3 star rating discourage you from buying but note that-the makers have sadly taken some cheap shortcuts from the fan they made in the past and buy doing that they should have also lowered the price. I would rather pay a couple bucks more for quality, my last one lasted for YEARS with even months of non stop 24 hour a day (on DC power)  use.

Title: How to cope when the power is off
Review Content: This is the 2nd time I've purchased this fan, and I wouldn't have needed to, if the cats hadn't knocked it off the window sill!  I absolutely can't sleep when the power is off and there is no air moving.  I have used this fan mostly with the AC adapter, but I always make sure I have sufficient batteries on hand to put in it when needed.  The first one lasted a LONG time, and I'm sure it would still be running without the intervention of some bad cats!

Title: Not your average little fan
Review Content: This is a very powerful little fan. I bought it because it supports batteries when the power is out. I live in Louisiana and when it's Hurricane season, we prepare with as many battery operated appliances as you can. This fan is very powerful, cools the room without ever putting it on high. When not on battery, I remove them and plug in. Works great, highly recommend.

When not on battery, I remove them and plug in. Works great, highly recommend.

Title: Little fan makes a Big difference
Review Content: I love these little fans. They're quiet but powerful. And easily switch between the power cord and battery power. I use it year round and love that even when the power goes out I can still sleep with a fan on. We've bought 4 or 5 and the only problem I ever had was after 3 years of daily use (24/7 I never turned it off) the motor began squeaking. They're cheap so I just replaced it. But with some oil for fan motors I probably wouldn't have had that problem.Easy to clean too. Take out the screws (some of them are recessed so I recommend using a magnetic screw driver) and you can clean the whole thing without too much fuss. But if you don't want to do that, I once took it outside and used a can of compressed air to clean the dust off the grills.

Title: This ran for over 24 hours on one set of batteries!
Review Content: What a great find. We had a devastating 100 mph storm last week which crippled the city. On day 3 of 90°+ temps and no power I finally looked on Amazon for something that might help. (We are now at day 6 and the fans are truly fantastic.)These fans. They are everything to me right now. They take 6 D size batteries so prepare for that. But over 24 hours of constant use … invaluable.They’re 10 inches and slender, lightweight, easy to put anywhere from a window ledge to high perch.Well made, they have permanent screws for the battery cover so you don’t lose them. Brilliant!These fans come with a wall adapter for when there is power.As for the effectiveness of them, I can say they are powerful enough to place across the room by 5 feet or so and still feel a breeze. I think this is described as a desk fan but it can be used for so much more.These things are life savers! I’m buying a third one today!

Title: Pricey, but works
Review Content: I purchased this for hurricane season in Florida. I didn't use it much or at all but I took it out of the box and have started using it when I sit outside to keep the mosquitoes away at night. I like to sit outside by my lake and it's not screened in so I put this on and I have no problems with them. Hopefully, I won't have to take it out for hurricane season when I have no power but if I do have no power at least I know I could be a little cooler.

We decided to purchase another because we used the first one when AC current went out at home or to keep our dog cool when traveling. Title: LOVE THIS FAN!!!
Review Content: Purchased a year ago! FINALLY got to use it when we lost power, works GREAT! Planning on buying another one when it goes on sale! A great fan to have when you live in an area where power loss happens sooner than later!
Manually Corrected Review Content: Purchased a year ago! FINALLY got to use it when we lost power, works GREAT! Planning on buying another one when it goes on sale! A great fan to have when you live in an area where power loss happens sooner than later!

Title: Great fan - going strong 5 years
Review Content: Absolutely great fan! Very quiet with good air flow. Ours has been steady for five years and still going strong. We usually use battery power and it goes for hours. When the battery power gets low, the fan slows down but keeps going. Recharging the 6 D cells does take a while though, so the AC power cord can come in handy.We have used this all over the house. I took it to my job for a few months to bring in fresh outdoor air when we re-opened after Covid. The fan sat in the window sill very nicely with the 6 D cells giving it a low center of gravity.At home, the portability is a strong point with no wires to get in the way and can be located anywhere.I added some felt to the bottom so it would not scratch furniture; that also helped quiet down vibration noise on one uneven surface. Some users might not like the slide switch, but I find that you don't accidentally turn it on or off with this type of switch.Size is for smaller area such as TV area, dinner table, kitchen, office etc. not for an entire room.If you want a reliable, quiet fan that you can place anywhere, go with this one !

Title: mixed feelings
Review Content: Purchased 2 just in time for Hurricane Beryl.... Lights/phone/internet/wifi...everything out for 7 days.  I was able to stay reasonably comfortable because of the battery operated fan. I had purchased 2 previously in anticipation of Hurricane season, but my sister's household needed them several months before Beryl..they worked perfectly!! I told her to keep them & I would order 2 more for my household.One worked perfectly, the second one I could not get to work at all!!  I was disappointed!! I don't want to say luckily, but my husband got sick and had to go the ER, and I was able to survive with the one fan.  We both could not have shared one fan during the power outage.

Title: An office life saver during the summer.
Review Content: When the heat started rising this summer and there was constant threat of losing power due to power grid sustainment or storms, I figured it would be better to finally have a few comfort systems already on hand. I bought two different fans for potential emergencies intending to see what happened. Fortunately, we did not end up losing power, but I was able to quickly evaluate the fans to see how much they could do to reduce normal use of  air conditioning. The first fan was a rechargeable box type, but the design seemed to inhibit the flow and although it was touted as 10", that was only the enclosure. The blades were about 7" and simply too small to circulate enough air. The Treva 10" is fabulous. Conditioned air does not reach my office well, so running this fan made all the difference. It is powerful, but quiet and beyond easy to just plop anywhere. I also bought a couple of eight packs of D-cell batteries against not having plug in power. Clearly, running on battery power should be for remote or emergency use only, but I am happy enough with everything else about this fan that I am going to order a couple more.

Title: Kind of cheap feeling but works
Review Content: Good- It works when outlet or battery powered. Decent air speed. Lightweight. Can charge things via USBBad- feels cheap, not dollar store but I'm concerned about it falling. Runs on D cells. Who has D cell batteries anymore? I'd rather use 12 AA or something, at least I have those. Fan Is already squeaking after 30 minutes of use.If I lived closer to a return location I'd send this back. But this fan is literally only for power outages in my case. I don't mind something subpar for emergencies. If you will use it often I'd go with a name brand.

Title: Gets the job done!
Review Content: This is a great battery powered fan that will absolutely get the job done in an emergency. I am writing this review in July in Texas on hour 30 with no electricity. I have four of these fans, but it only took one to keep us cool all night! Be sure to buy lots of D batteries as each unit requires 6 to run. I’m on year two with these fans in our emergency kit, and they’ve been of great use. (Also works great with the provided plug. I keep one in my kitchen year round.)

Title: Amazing Fans
Review Content: These fans have been life savers during Hurricane Beryl. We hand no power for 5 days and already had 2 of these fans. Houston in the summer is no joke. Thankfully we were able to get good amount of air flow with 2 of these fans blowing constantly. We ordered more for our families who were also without power and have been recommending them to everyone. Generators are expensive, but if these power outages keep happening we might have to get one. Until then these help out in a pinch.

We ordered more for our families who were also without power and have been recommending them to everyone. Generators are expensive, but if these power outages keep happening we might have to get one. Until then these help out in a pinch.

Title: Saving my summer!
Review Content: I got this fan because of the current heatwave. I needed a fan that could be battery operated as we have at least 1-2 power outages in the summer. This fan can so be plugged in, which is a huge bonus since batteries are expensive. I love being on my balcony and I can sit outside with this fan and my shade cloth in mid-90s temps. I also love it on my bedroom night stand when sleeping. Keeps me cool enough on the lower speed that I can set the thermostat higher and save $$ on central air overnight.

Title: A brave little hero in the savage outage heat.
Review Content: Been through a hell of a time having no power for 5 days in Tulsa Yallklahoma and ordered this in a pinch after the first night of being unable to sleep.It has run well past 24 hours on a single set of 6 D batteries while on its low setting and it gets the job very well done. I can actually sleep without a heat episode every hour. Lounging in the couch is just fine too.The air flow on this bad boi is conical, so for better results, you will want it about 2 or 3 feet away. The fan is also slightly tilted up and does not flex.You will need a Phillps screwdriver to get into the battery compartment. It comes with an ac adapter if you have a power source to hook it up to.Definitely buying a second one when this bout is all over and done with. Thanks for the hyper carry Treva.

Title: Narrow profile fits well on window shelf. Only the high power setting works.
Review Content: So I rounded down on this one. It's between a 4 and 4.5.I bought it so I'd have a fan to put in the window that would blow fresh air toward my bed, without blowing it directly on my face. It's a delicate balancing act. Anyway, the fan fits perfectly on our sill, and the cord was *just* long enough to plug in.The fan has two settings, low and high. Low setting isn't getting enough power, I think? It cuts in and out.  Hard to sleep when the motor keeps slowing down, almost dying, then speeding back up.High power works fine, but it's not very powerful. It's spinning its little heart out, making a good drowning-all-other-noises racket, but it's not pulling a whole lot of air in.I can imagine this would be perfect for a smaller space, like a camper or a little cabin. But it's not doing much to cool down my medium-sized bedroom.On the other hand, it reduces the noise of the dogs barking next door.On the other, other hand, the reason the barking is so loud is because I have the window open.Bottom line: if I'm sitting right next to the fan on the computer, it provides a nice air flow. A few feet away on the bed, not so effective.

Title: Pleasantly Surprised
Review Content: I rarely write reviews, but I had to write one for this fan.  I bought two of these fans back in 2021 for camping.  I not only take them camping, I also travel with one of them in my suitcase.  The output of breeze is pretty good for the size of the fan.  It was a life saver when we went camping last month in Florida.  During camping I walked around the island carrying the fan everywhere it was so hot.  The battery life was at minimum 3 days.  I traveled to my son's house and used it every night to sleep (because who don't need a fan while they are sleeping) and I managed to get 6 nights of battery life.  I use the Amazon Basic D batteries (24 pack) and they work perfect.  I have nothing negative to say about this and highly recommend.

Title: Very Cool
Review Content: Bought these for hurricane Irma, but I did that too late so they ended up being delivered about a week or so afterwards (delays due primarily to hurricane)Since then, I had these in my "emergency closet" and was resorting to all sorts of contraptions (including a DYI camping A/C unit) until finally trying these outLet me tell you, these things are COOL! We camped out early September in Florida. I connected one to my Jackery 240, and the other was on batteries. In the middle of the night, I had to turn mine off because it was too cool. To be fair, I had it blowing right on meI looked at power consumption for about 6 hours and it was at about 12W, so with approximately 6 hours of use, it only consumed 30% of my JackeryThe other fan, which had been on all night didn't consume the batteries entirelyThe only reason I'm giving these a 4 star is because there are a couple of things they can do better1) You're going to want the pivoting base. Propping these against shoes or the cooler was a bit awkward2) The power cord doesn't store anywhere in the unit. I had to tape it to the fan for storage. The battery slot could have been designed to store it easily. Just a bit of lack of foresightIn all, a great fan and surprisingly cool. I really wish I hadn't spent all that money with other contraptions before trying these firstDefinitely get as a low energy consumption option for post-hurricane supplies

Title: Battery Powered Function Does Not Work
Review Content: I hardly ever give a negative review. Normally if I don;t like something I just don't review it. But in this case I am going to review this fan because I am pretty angry right now. Why, you may ask?  Because I specifically bought this fan a couple months ago to get ready for hurricane season. It is deathly hot where I live when the power goes out and I thought if I at least had a fan I could get my sweat to evaporate if it happens and cool me off. I plugged the fan in and it worked beautifully. So I put it back in it's box and hoped I'd never need to use it during a storm, but if I did I would have a brand new fan ready to go.When I heard a hurricane was approaching I decided to come here to the reviews and  see how long people were saying a set of batteries would run the fan for. And I happened to read a couple of people saying their battery function didn't work. My stomach sank as I had no time left to prepare. I'd just ordered 75 dollars worth of D batteries specifically to run this fan after going to the store for them and everything was already sold out. Batteries, fans, etc.But Amazon could at least deliver them before the storm. (Later that day I couldn't order anything else without the arrival date being 8 days away due to the storm interfering with traffic and deliveries.) So I quickly put batteries in the fan to see if mine worked or not and to my horror it did not. No matter which way I stuck them in, the fan just will not work with batteries in it. And for those of you saying it does work but the fan can't be plugged in at the same time, mine was not plugged in. The people here saying it isn't working are not idiots. Their fans and my fan just don't work on batteries. I opened 2 brand new sets and neither of them got the fan to come on.So I ended up cancelling the big D battery order and ordering 2 mini little fans that barely put out any air, along with loads of AA batteries to run them. And luckily I was within those few hours that Amazon was still sending out 2 day deliveries because otherwise I'd be facing who knows how long of 100 degree temps without power after the storm comes.Had I not decided to come see what people were saying about how many hours the fan runs on  a set of batteries I'd never have known until my power went off that I had no useable fans. And I'd be sitting on 75 dollars worth of batteries I'd bought for it that I didn't need.That's why I'm writing the bad review. Because I know some of you are trying to find a battery powered fan before the hurricane and if you buy this one there is a 50/50 chance you will get one of the one's that don't work while battery run. To add insult to injury I paid 22 for this fan and it is now 14. And I bought it 2 months ago so the return window is closed. On the bright side, it DOES work while plugged in so I will just use it as an extra electric powered fan for general use. It works great when it is plugged in. So I will give it 2 stars instead of 1.

Title: It works, but with a catch
Review Content: When power goes out here in Florida, there is no air conditioning. So battery operated fans are a must. The fan I purchased is light weight, compact and moves the air very well. However, when the batteries are in place the battery cover will not close. The fan would not work without a cover for the batteries. So I tried using duct tape. That may not look good, but since it seemed to work, and to avoid the hassle of returning the fan I decided to keep it. I hope that works long enough to at least get me through hurricane season.

Title: "Cool" fan with Nice Features
Review Content: When the power goes out in Florida and you have no A/C and no fans running for a few days, it gets awfully miserable. What I needed was a battery-operated fan to keep cool. This fan is exactly what I needed. It's small enough to place just about anywhere and it gives you a good breeze. Both low and high power are quiet and vibration-free. You can use batteries or the included cable to connect to the house current. You can also charge your cell phone from the D size batteries since it has a USB connection. The only slight problem I encountered was when I was trying to close the battery cover when installing the 6 D batteries. But I finally found a way to do it without too much trouble. If anyone needs a video on the easy way to do it, I can provide one.

Title: Decent
Review Content: I bought this fan for my office which gets quite hot this time of year. Many desk fans are more expensive than this and you get what you pay for, so keep that in mind. The fan is powered via plug-in or D batteries. I've only used it plugged in so I don't know how long it will last with batteries. There are also two modes for airflow, high and low.It is cooling for about a foot away on high mode. Unfortunately it is quite loud so I cannot use it during meetings or phone calls. If you are using this for sleep or other personal use it shouldn't be too loud unless you have sensitive hearing. If you are using this for a desk or next to the bed it will be sufficiently cooling. If you are using it for a further distance you probably won't feel too much air.So, the fan is decently loud and the cooling power is very light. For the price I can't complain too much but if you are looking for a quite/more effective fan I would look elsewhere. But for the price it is sufficient.

Although it was still very hot inside, these really did help me and they stayed on for a long time. I just made sure I had battery back up I have another fan that doesn’t work as nice as this one.

Title: Impressed considering the price with remote
Review Content: UPDATE:  I've had this fan almost a year now. It has been running constantly last summer into fall (on high) and 3 months so far this year (mid to high setting).I have had no issues with unusual noises, odors, or failures. I've been using the oscillation continuously as well for the last 6 weeks (all day, all night, every day as I did last summer/fall without oscillation) For $40 I consider this a good purchase and would buy another if/when needed.The only improvement suggestion I would make to the manufacturer is to increase the range of the remote. You have to be fairly close; approx. 3-foot range directly in front of the sensor on the front of the unit. I haven't needed to change the battery in the remote, however as it runs continually, I'm not using it to turn on/off daily, but this year have occasionally changed the speed between medium and high using the remote.Original rating of 5 stars; no change.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I've only had this fan for a couple weeks, but it has been running on high setting 24/7 the entire time without the oscillation. So far (🤞), no noises or issues with functionality.  It does provide a little background sound (like a fan will do) but it's not out of the ordinary/excessively loud. It's used in a respectably-sized bedroom,  not overly large,  but roomy, with a second fan on the other side of the room to create circular air flow while the AC is out.It's July and hot in the south and although fans don't cool the air like AC, I'm not sweltering with this set up.  One is set higher than the other as this one isn't very tall, but also doesn't need a large surface space either.This would be a nice fan for a small office space or smaller bedroom alone with AC.  You do need to point the remote directly at the LED readout (not from the side) for it to respond, but that isn't odd.  The remote came with a battery installed; I can't speak to the longevity of the battery provided yet.  The LED readout is a little bright (white not blue) but isn't a problem for me as it isn't right next to my face.  If used on a bedside table it might be bothersome to some if facing the bed.  It lights up,  but it doesn't "project" a lot of light.Speed tests from approx 6' away:Setting 1 is hardly audible,  but useless unless you are right next to it; air flow is miniscule at 6'.Setting 2 isn't much different from 1, but might be fine sitting at a desk with this by your feet or on the desk for slight air movement.  Still extremely quiet.Setting 3 still quite quiet with a light breeze close upSetting 4 start to hear the fan, light breeze close upSetting 5 starts to sound like a fan is actually running and begins to put out air flow many other small fans might on low.Setting 6 slightly higher than 5 in sound and air flow.Setting 7 a bit louder than 6, as some small fans might sound on medium or high with air flow felt 6' away.Setting 8, sound gets louder, but quieter than some fans on medium with a definite breeze 6' away.  It won't blow you over,  but this isn't a shop fan either.  With AC, this should provide air flow in a small room without another fan, or cooling effect up close by the bed or on a desk.With 8 levels, oscillation, REMOTE, & small footprint, if this unit lasts a while it will be worth the $40 price tag. However, if you need a lot of air flow across the room, a large fan (Vornado) or multiple small fans (I also have a stationary 8 or 10" by this maker for $20) would be recommended.  A small fan isn't going to do the work of a large fan, but this one does a pretty good job for it's size. The few small fans with remotes are more expensive.  The big test is how long will it last. With my continual use, if it lasts thru the end of the summer on high I'll consider it a good buy for the price.  I've had other less expensive small fans that worked great but did not oscillate or tilt (stationary) and certainty didn't come with a remote... or a strange name! LolIf it quits working in a short amount of time, I'll update my review.

The remote needs to be pointed directly to the front. There is a Night feature, which turns off the lights, which is a plus. The cord is about 5’, or less which you may need to take into consideration for where you plan to use it. It would be best on a counter or table top, it is too short to stand alone on the floor to be productive. I feel the perfect price point for this would be between 14 to 24 American dollars.

Title: Too small for me
Review Content: This fan is only effective in quite a small space, and that makes its features and price seem like overkill to me. As other reviewers have noted, the lower settings (1-3) are very light breeze and very quiet. They’re fine for maintaining some air circulation but don’t help to cool very well. The upper settings are more powerful but also more noisy. The main issue in my eyes is that the fan is very short. When it is set on the floor you can’t feel it at face height, even if you’re sitting in a chair. When placed on a table it can be effective; however, the design results in quite a narrow column of moving air and the oscillation feature is quite a slow sweep. I find that this just doesn’t cool a space (or me) as effectively as something like a round oscillating fan. I bought it for use in my bedroom but have ended up using it on the counter in the kitchen to blow right at me (and only me) while cooking in hot weather. Since it has to be close by to be effective, the remote control seems superfluous… and it has to be pointed at the sensor just right… which often necessitates walking over to the fan to get the right angle. Is it a fan that moves air? Yes. Does it work? Yes. Would I buy another? Nope!

Title: Quiet enough for the bedroom
Review Content: I got this fan to use for my bedroom to keep cool at night. It replaces a 12 inch box fan that was just too loud.  The fan stands 16 inches tall and is 4 inches wide. The airflow comes out the grill in front and it's a narrow current. You feel the breeze about six feet across. That's perfect for sleeping at night.i tested the noise level. The background noise with nothing on in my bedroom is about 32 dB. When the fan is on at level 4 out of 8 at a distance of 10 feet the sound level is 36 dB.  If the fan is turned up too high at level 8 the noise was at 47 dB.  For comparison my old box fan at low setting was 47 dB and at medium it was  51 dB or more It also rattled and this was very disturbing, where this new tower fan doesn't rattle, and it's a calming breeze sound. One thing to remember, the decibel scale is logarithmic. It means when you go from 32 to 33 dB, that's not one times more noisy, it's 10 times louder. So going from 36 dB with the new fan to the old box fan at 47 dB when it's turn to low setting. It's a huge difference.This fan oscillates back and forth and has a timer and a remote, but I have no reason to use the remote.I like this fan for bedroom use. The airflow's not as good as a little box fan, but it's perfectly fine to get some cool sleep.

Title: Great bedside fan, but....
Review Content: I bought this for my bedside table to provide a breeze at night.  I went with this model because of the 8 speeds since most 3 speed fans are too high even on the lowest setting.  Works great!  Remote is simplified and easy to understand.The only drawback and the reason for only 3 stars is that the air vents do not tilt up and down.  As such, you need to be on the exact same height level as the fan in order to get any breeze.  Case in point, my nightstand is 4 inches higher than my mattress and when the fan was turned on and pointed at my pillow, I got hardly any breeze.  I had to put something under the base in order to tilt the entire unit downward.  Not ideal, but it does the trick.

Title: Finally a quiet fan for sleep
Review Content: This is the most quiet fan I have purchased.  I have tried 2 other fans, "Abolee Tower Fan for Bedroom" and "Honeywell HTF210B QuietSet Personal Table Fan", and while the Honeywell was definitley quiet at its lowest setting (there is 4 total), it was not powerful enough.  The other fan by Abolee was very noisy at its lowest setting.  Finally tried this Dr. Prepare Tower Fan for Bedroom 25dB and it was very quiet at Level 1 and 2 (there are a total of 8 levels).  I used it last night while I was sleeping, with a timer for 2 hours, and had a pleasant night of rest.  It has all the basic features I needed:  Timer, Oscilating and 8 speed settings.  It also comes with a remote, which I don't use much, except to "Mute" the sound of the buttons.  So happy I can now sleep with a fan on and not be bothered with the fan noise.
